Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 IEEE International Conference on Trust, Privacy and Security in Intelligent Systems, and Applications (IEEE TPS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The IEEE International Conference on Trust, Privacy and Security in Intelligent Systems and Applications (IEEE 2019), held in Los Angeles, CA, Dec 12-14, 2019, focuses on the issues related to trust, privacy and security and their interplay with artificial intelligence in the context of smart and intelligent systems. It provides an opportunity for researchers to discuss research results at the intersection of artificial intelligence and machine learning with cognitive science and behavioral science and putting human in the loop. Through peer-reviewed technical research papers, invited keynote talks and panel discussions, the conference brings together leaders from interdisciplinary communities to understand the broader set of challenges of and explore holistic solutions for the highly interconnected, AI enhanced digital world.

This award supports approximately 15 students to participate in the conference. To facilitate increased level of participation, partial support may be provided to students who have some other means of covering part of their expenses. Selection criteria include evidence of interest in the field as demonstrated by statement of research interests, CV showing research output, coursework and/or project experience, etc., recommendation letter, and a statement on how participation in the conference would benefit the studentâ€™s research and education. Preference is given to students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the attendance of students to the First IEEE International Conference on Trust, Privacy and Security in Intelligent Systems, and Applications (IEEE TPS), which has been established as an international multidisciplinary forum for the presentation of state-of-the-art innovations, and discussion among academic, industrial researchers, policymakers, and practitioners on issues related to trust, privacy and security in emerging smart and intelligent systems and applications. The conference took place December 12-14, 2019 in Los Angeles, CA, USA. The technical program of IEEE TPS 2019 featured three keynotes, four plenary panels, two industry keynotes, and multiple sessions of vision and regular research papers.

IEEE TPS 2019 was co-located with the Fifth IEEE Conference on Collaboration and Internet Computing (IEEE CIC 2019), and the First International Conference on Cognitive Machine Intelligence (IEEE CogMI 2019). The three co-located conferences brought together a broad set of interdisciplinary communities in one venue to understand the challenges and explore holistic solutions for a highly interconnected, AI-enhanced digital world.

The travel awards supported through this grant enabled the participation of students who would be otherwise unable to attend IEEE TPS 2019. By attending IEEE TPS, students were exposed to problems and ideas in the intersection of two critical areas of research, i.e., Trust/Privacy/Security and Artificial Intelligence. The students were able to present their research and interact with established researchers. The keynotes and technical panels further exposed students to ideas discussed by distinguished scientists/engineers. Moreover, a unique mentoring/advising session was organized for students that featured a panel of well-established researchers and role models in the field.

The criteria for selecting applications for awards included conference participation, presenting a paper, commitment to research, research interests aligned with IEEE TPS areas, and financial need. Also, preference was given to students from underrepresented groups. We received 22 applications and were able to award 16 travel grants to students enrolled in US universities.
